title: Cats. 78–79  Two Fragments of Inlays Depicting Theater Masks

<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body">Fragment of an Inlay Depicting a Theater Mask  
Late 1st century B.C./early 1st century A.D.  
Egyptian  
Glass, mosaic glass technique; 3.6 × 1.4 × 0.4 cm (1 7/16 × 9/16 × 1/8 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Charles L. Hutchinson, 1894.783

Fragment of an Inlay Depicting a Theater Mask  
Late 1st century B.C./early 1st century A.D.  
Egyptian  
Glass, mosaic glass technique; 2.2 × 1.5 × 0.3 cm (7/8 × 5/8 × 1/8 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1949.1306

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">These inlays represent Greek-style theater masks. Susan Auth has studied this material for years and has suggested that these belong to a series of female characters that would have been recognized from New Comedy. These plaques seems related to the red-haired courtesan or the more generic Maenad that often accompanied Dionysos. Charis Mahnke, who has studied these plaques more recently, considers them more generically, as female masks with red hair.

The complete image would have been formed by placing two slices, cut from a long bar, one reversed from the same cane, next to each other to form a complete face. While it was common for dealers and collectors to create complete faces in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, there are a few examples of plaques preserved from the period where the two-part face was still attached to the wooden backing and retained additional decorative elements.

Inlays like these would have appealed to the Roman elite, who had a tradition of attending theatrical performances. Cat. 78 is a variation of a well-known type; examples of it exist in many American and European collections. Cat. 79, which seems to be a woman, appears to be unique; the three preserved hair elements are extraordinary.  
Sidney Goldstein
